content: steek practice piece by nancy mcelmurry ©2025 this is a little piece designed to allow you to practice placing steeks in stranded knitting four steek areas are included so that you may practice different methods of preparing the steek for cutting just a tidbit the pattern used here is a variation of a typical oxo pattern found in many fairisle garments here the x and o are isolated if you overlap them so that the side stitches match up you would have the oxo repeat if you would like to play with color placement as for fairisle knitting i suggest changing colors every two rounds round 7 is the pivot round the pivot round generally uses pop colors which will be only used in this round please read through the directions before beginning for best results 1 materials yarn non-superwash wool in any weight from fingering to worsted will work for this exercise two or more contrasting colors are needed designate your colors as dark and light round up some leftovers the light color s will be the background color s the dark will be the pattern color if you want to play with color placement as in fairisle knitting you can use colored pencils and color the chart to your liking needles 16 circular needles in size appropriate for yarn an example is us 3 for fingering weight us size 5-8 for dk to worsted depending on how tightly or loosely you knit stitch markers 1 unique 9 additional it is helpful to use colored markers and color code the marker lines on the chart to match your markers also needed will be scrap yarn sharp scissors crochet hook smaller than your needle size or sewing machine or needle and sewing thread directions cast on using the color you have the most of cast on 96 stitches with a long tail or crochet cast on knit one row join to work in the round being careful not to twist place the unique marker at the beginning of the round knit the next round placing markers as follows *k5 pm k17 pm k9 pm k13 pm k4* place a marker to mark the half round which is the left edge of the chart repeat from * to * one time on the following round introduce your second color and work the 13 rounds of the chart you will use both colors in these rounds if you would like to practice color placement as for fairisle knitting indicate on the chart which colors you will be using for which rounds colors are generally shaded either from dark to light or light to dark and are reversed on the upper half the middle round is a pivot round which should be pop colors different from your others when chart is finished work a round or two all in one color bind off
